data.title: Bells will toll for New Jersey's 350th anniversary
data.meta_description: Numerous churches in Burlington County will ring in the 350th anniversary of New Jersey’s founding Tuesday.\n The churches will join houses of worship statewide in commemorating the milestone by ringi…
data.text:
Numerous churches in Burlington County will ring in the 350th anniversary of New Jersey’s founding Tuesday.

The churches will join houses of worship statewide in commemorating the milestone by ringing their bells for a minute at noon.

The date marks the 350th anniversary of the signing of a 1664 land grant when English noblemen John Lord Berkeley and Sir George Carteret were awarded the property between the Delaware and Hudson rivers by King Charles II and his brother, James, the Duke of York.

The land later was named New Jersey in honor of Carteret’s ancestral British home, the Isle of Jersey.

Following are some of the churches that have indicated they will participate in the ceremonial bell sounding:

Beverly:

St. Stephen’s Episcopal Church, Warren Street

Bordentown City:

St. Mary Church, Crosswicks Street

Burlington City:

St. Mary’s Episcopal Church, West Broad Street

Burlington Township:

Assemblies of God New Jersey, Columbus Road

Cinnaminson:

St. Paul Baptist Church, Bannard Street

Delanco:

Dobbins Memorial United Methodist Church, Union Avenue

Delran:

Delran United Methodist Church, Conrow Road

Edgewater Park:

Beverly Presbyterian Church, Warren Street

Fieldsboro:

Fieldsboro United Methodist Church, Second Street

Moorestown:

First Presbyterian Church of Moorestown, Bridgeboro Road; Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, West Main Street; Trinity Episcopal Church, West Main Street

Mount Laurel:

St. John Neumann Church, Walton Avenue

Palmyra:

Central Baptist Church, East Maple Avenue

Riverside:

Zion Lutheran Church, Fairview Street and Pavilion Avenue

Riverton:

Calvary Presbyterian Church, Fourth Street; Christ Episcopal Church, Main Street; Sacred Heart Church, Thomas Avenue

Willingboro:

St. Paul United Methodist Church, Levitt Parkway

Sen. Diane Allen, R-7th of Edgewater Park, said she was pleased so many county churches were choosing to participate in the ceremony.

“It’s appropriate that we join together in commemorating the history of this great state,” Allen said in a statement. “The bells tolling on Tuesday will be a reminder of New Jersey’s unique history and how the events 350 years ago forever shaped this state and nation, and, in turn, each of us.”

In addition to the bells, Allen and other members of the Senate welcomed Alan Simon Crowcroft, a representative from the Isle of Jersey, to the Statehouse in Trenton on Monday, and the chamber passed a resolution celebrating the ties between New Jersey and its original namesake.
